facts.text: Criminal Appeal No. 130 of 1956 is an appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated May 12, 1955, of the Punjab High Court.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No. 130 of 1956. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated May 12, 1955, of the Punjab High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 52-D of 1954, arising out of the judgment and order dated December 6, 1954, of the Court of the Special Judge at Delhi in Corruption Case No. 1 of 1954.

facts.text: Punjab High Court judgment in Criminal Appeal No. 52-D of 1954 arose out of judgment dated December 6, 1954, of Special Judge at Delhi in Corruption Case No. 1 of 1954.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No. 130 of 1956. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated May 12, 1955, of the Punjab High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 52-D of 1954, arising out of the judgment and order dated December 6, 1954, of the Court of the Special Judge at Delhi in Corruption Case No. 1 of 1954. 1038 C. Chatterjee and C. V. L. Narayan, for the appellant in Cr. A. No. 130 of 56.

facts.text: Appellant in Criminal Appeal No. 130 of 1956 was convicted under s. 5(2) of the Prevention of Corruption Act and sentenced to six months simple imprisonment by Special Judge, Delhi.

anchor.surface_text: In Criminal Appeal No. 130 of 1956, the appellant was convicted under s. 5 2  of the Act and sentenced to six months simple imprisonment by the Special Judge, Delhi. He appealed against his conviction and sentence to the Punjab High Court.

facts.text: Appellant in Cr A No 130/56 appealed to Punjab High Court against conviction and sentence.

anchor.surface_text: He appealed against his conviction and sentence to the Punjab High Court. That Court while admitting the appeal issued notice upon the appellant to show cause why his sentence should not be enhanced.

facts.text: Punjab High Court dismissed appeal of appellant in Cr A 130/56 and enhanced sentence to two years rigorous imprisonment.

anchor.surface_text: That Court while admitting the appeal issued notice upon the appellant to show cause why his sentence should not be enhanced. The High Court ultimately dismissed his appeal and enhanced the sentence of six months imprisonment to two years rigorous imprisonment.

facts.text: Special leave in Criminal Appeal No. 130 of 1956 limited to question of jurisdiction for want of sanction under s.6 Prevention of Corruption Act.

anchor.surface_text: Special leave in Criminal Appeal No. 130 of 1956 was limited to the question whether the trial court had jurisdiction to take cognizance of the offence for want of sanction under s. 6 of the Prevention of Corruption Act, 1947 11 of 1947 , hereinafter referred to as the Act.

facts.text: In Criminal Appeal No. 25 of 1956, appellant applied to Allahabad High Court under s.561A CrPC for quashing proceedings before Special Judge; application dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: In Criminal Appeal No. 25 of 1956 the appellant had applied to the Allahabad High Court under s. 561A of the Code of Criminal Procedure for the quashing of the proceedings pending against him before the Special Judge. The application was dismissed.

facts.text: It is admitted that at the time Special Judge purported to take cognizance, appellants were not public servants and no order of sanction under s.6 Act was on record.

anchor.surface_text: It is admitted that at the time the Special Judges concerned purported to take cognizance the appellants were not public servants and that no order of sanction under s. 6 of the Act by a competent authority was on the record.

facts.text: At the time appellants are alleged to have committed the offence, they were public servants.

anchor.surface_text: At the time that the appellants are alleged to have committed the offence they were public servants. Section 6 of the Act states Previous sanction necessary for prosecution  1  No court shall take cognizance of an offence punishable under section 161 or section 164 or section 165 of the Indian Penal Code

facts.text: Judgment delivered on December 3, 1957 by IMAM J.

anchor.surface_text: K. Daphtary, Solicitor-General of India, A.M. Chatterjee, R. Khanna and R. H. Dhebar, for the respondent in both the appeals. 1957. December 3. The following Judgment of the Court was delivered by IMAM J.-A question of law, common to these appeals by special leave, requires determination hence they were heard together.

facts.text: Appellant in Cr A 25/56 appointed Deputy Assistant Director Enforcement in Ministry of Industry and Commerce on March 25, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: Criminal Appeal 25 of 1956. In this appeal apart from the question that the court could not take cognizance of the offence alleged against the appellant without a previous sanction of a competent authority, additional points had been taken for quashing the prosecution pending against him. The appellant was appointed Deputy Assistant Director Enforcement in the Ministry of Industry and Commerce on March 25, 1949 and was promoted to the office of Assistant Director on July 14, 1949.

facts.text: Appellant in Cr A 25/56 promoted to Assistant Director on July 14, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: and was promoted to the office of Assistant Director on July 14, 1949. It was alleged that he accepted on September 11, 1951, a sum Rs. 10,000 as bribe in part payment out of an agreed amount of Rs. 30,000. An enquiry under r. 55 of the Civil Service Rules took place and thereafter he was dismissed from service on September 25, 1953.

facts.text: Appellant in Cr A 25/56 alleged to have accepted Rs. 10,000 as bribe on September 11, 1951, part payment of Rs. 30,000.

anchor.surface_text: It was alleged that he accepted on September 11, 1951, a sum Rs. 10,000 as bribe in part payment out of an agreed amount of Rs. 30,000. An enquiry under r. 55 of the Civil Service Rules took place and thereafter he was dismissed from service on September 25, 1953.

facts.text: Appellant in Cr A 25/56 dismissed from service on September 25, 1953 after enquiry under r.55 Civil Service Rules.

anchor.surface_text: An enquiry under r. 55 of the Civil Service Rules took place and thereafter he was dismissed from service on September 25, 1953. In the meantime, it appears that correspondence had ensued between the appellant and the Government.

facts.text: Final report under s.173 CrPC submitted on September 18, 1952 stating prosecution recommended but Ministry ordered departmental dealing.

anchor.surface_text: On September 18, 1952, a final report was submitted to the court under s. 173 of the Code of Criminal Procedure wherein it was stated that although a prosecution was recommended, the order of the Ministry of Commerce and Industry was that the appellant would be dealt with departmentally.

facts.text: Magistrate on September 19, 1952 approved closing of investigation, discharged appellant from bail, directed return of Rs.10,000 to complainant.

anchor.surface_text: On September 19, 1952, the Magistrate, by his order, approved of the closing of the investigation, discharged the appellant from his bail and directed that the sum of Rs. 10,000 seized from him, was to be returned to the complainant.

facts.text: Prosecution against appellant in Cr A 25/56 recommenced on February 11, 1954 on fresh complaint.

anchor.surface_text: The prosecution of the appellant was, however, recommenced on February II,, 1954, on the same materials and same allegations but on a fresh complaint.

facts.text: Court held that there was no positive refusal of sanction for prosecution of appellant in Cr A 25/56.

anchor.surface_text: We have examined the correspondence which has been referred to in the petition for special leave and which is to be found on the record of this case. There is nothing in them to establish the allegation that a sanction for the prosecution of the appellant was positively refused.

facts.text: Appellants had ceased to be public servants at the time the court took cognizance of the offences.

anchor.surface_text: In the present appeals, admittedly, the appellants had ceased to be public servants at the time the court took cognizance of the offences alleged to have been committed by them as public servants.

facts.text: Provisions of s.6 Prevention of Corruption Act did not apply as appellants not public servants at time of cognizance.

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly the provisions of s. 6 of the Act did not apply and the prosecution against them was not vitiated by the lack of a previous sanction by a competent authority.

facts.text: No sanction necessary before court takes cognizance if accused ceased to be public servant, though was at time of offence.

anchor.surface_text: The real controversy in these appeals is whether such a sanction is required before a court can take cognizance in the case of a person who is not a public servant at the time the court is asked to take cognizance, although the offence alleged against him was committed by him as a public servant.

Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated May 12, 1955, of the Punjab High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 52-D of 1954, arising out of the judgment and order dated December 6, 1954, of the Court of the Special Judge at Delhi in Corruption Case No. 1 of 1954.

Special leave in Criminal Appeal No. 130 of 1956 was limited to the question whether the trial court had jurisdiction to take cognizance of the offence for want of sanction under s. 6 of the Prevention of Corruption Act, 1947 (11 of 1947), hereinafter referred to as the Act.

concepts.interpretation: No court shall take cognizance unless accused is public servant at time of cognizance; sanction required only if person is still public servant then.

anchor.surface_text: In Criminal Appeal No. 130 of 1956, the appellant was convicted under s. 5(2) of the Act and sentenced to six months simple imprisonment by the Special Judge, Delhi.

concepts.unlisted_description: Punishment for criminal misconduct by public servant.

anchor.surface_text: whether there was any necessity for a sanction under s. 6 of the Act before a court could take cognizance of an offence under s. 161 of the Indian Penal Code or s. 5(2) of the Act or both, alleged to have been committed by a person who at the time the court was asked to take cognizance was not a public servant but was so at the time of the commission of the offence.

concepts.interpretation: Offence punishable under s.6 PC Act requiring sanction if public servant at cognizance.
concepts.unlisted_description: Public servant taking gratification other than legal remuneration.

anchor.surface_text: Section 6 of the Act states Previous sanction necessary for prosecution (1) No court shall take cognizance of an offence punishable under section 161 or section 164 or section 165 of the Indian Penal Code (Act 45 of 1860), or under sub-section (2) of section 5 of this Act, alleged to have been committed by a public servant,

concepts.unlisted_description: Public servant obtaining valuable thing without consideration.

anchor.surface_text: Section 6 of the Act states Previous sanction necessary for prosecution (1) No court shall take cognizance of an offence punishable under section 161 or section 164 or section 165 of the Indian Penal Code (Act 45 of 1860), or under sub-section (2) of section 5 of this Act, alleged to have been committed by a public servant,

concepts.unlisted_description: Public servant obtaining valuable thing from person with whom he is bound to deal.

anchor.surface_text: In Criminal Appeal No. 25 of 1956 the appellant had applied to the Allahabad High Court under s. 561A of the Code of Criminal Procedure for the quashing of the proceedings pending against him before the Special Judge. The application was dismissed.

Reliance was also placed upon certain decisions construing the provisions of s. 197 of the Code of Criminal Procedure. Reference was also made to Art. 361 of the Constitution and s. 197A of the Code of Criminal Procedure in aid of the construction which the learned Counsel contended for with reference to the words used in s. 6 of the Act.

concepts.interpretation: Protection applies only if public servant at time of accusation/cognizance; analogy supports s.6 PC Act interpretation.

holdings.text: The provisions of s. 6 of the Prevention of Corruption Act did not apply where the appellants had ceased to be public servants at the time the court took cognizance of the offences, and thus the prosecution was not vitiated by lack of previous sanction.

anchor.surface_text: In the present appeals, admittedly, the appellants had ceased to be public servants at the time the court took cognizance of the offences alleged to have been committed by them as public servants. Accordingly the provisions of s. 6 of the Act did

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.6(1) requires two conditions: (1) offence committed by public servant, (2) accused still a public servant (removable from office by competent authority) at time of cognizance; literal meaning unambiguous.

holdings.text: No sanction under s.6 is necessary before a court takes cognizance of offences under ss.161,164,165 IPC or s.5(2) PCA if the accused is no longer a public servant at that time, even if he was at the time of offence.

anchor.surface_text: the conclusion is inevitable that at the time a court is asked to take cognizance not only the offence must have been committed by a public servant but the person accused is still a public servant removable from his office by a competent authority

holdings.reasoning_summary: Clear words in s.6(1) impose dual requirements; clause (c) implies current office-holding; s.6(2) confirms by reference to removal authority at offence time only if still PS.

holdings.text: There was no positive refusal of sanction for prosecution of the appellant in Criminal Appeal No.25 of 1956; Government merely preferred departmental proceedings.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Examination of correspondence shows no explicit refusal, only choice of departmental action pending further enquiry; more evidence possible post-enquiry.

holdings.text: Recommencing prosecution on fresh complaint after prior discharge (due to no cognizance taken as still PS then) is not an abuse of court process when accused no longer PS.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Prior stage was pre-cognizance discharge (sanction lacking then); fresh complaint post-cessation of PS status allows cognizance without sanction; no promise not to prosecute.

holdings.text: Words of s.6(1) PCA are clear and must be given their natural meaning without recourse to purposive interpretation or external aids.

anchor.surface_text: In construing the provisions of a statute it is essential for a court, in the first instance, to give effect to the natural meaning of the words used therein, if those words are clear enough.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Primary rule of interpretation: literal meaning if unambiguous; no ambiguity here, unlike cited cases like Seaford Court Estates.

holdings.text: s.197 CrPC protects public servants from prosecution without sanction only if they remain public servants at time of accusation/cognizance.

anchor.surface_text: s. 197 of the Code affords no protection to a person who is not a public servant at the time he is accused of an offence before a court although at the time he committed

holdings.reasoning_summary: Consistent view of Calcutta, Bombay, Allahabad, Nagpur High Courts; analogous policy but s.6 construed independently.

precedents.citation: Seaford Court Estates Ltd. v. Asher 1 1949 2 K. B. 481, 498

anchor.surface_text: Observations of Denning L. J. as he then was, in the case of Seaford Court Estates Ltd. v. Asher 1 were relied upon by Mr. Chatterjee. It is, however, clear that the observations of the learned Judge were made with reference to the provision of a statute which was ambiguous.

precedents.case_name: Seaford Court Estates Ltd v Asher
precedents.cited_proposition: In construing ambiguous statutes, courts may look to legislative intention beyond literal words, supplementing the written word
precedents.cited_holding: Observations of Denning LJ on statutory interpretation where language is ambiguous

precedents.citation: S. Y. Patil v. Vyankatswami 2 I. L. R. 1939 Nag. 419

anchor.surface_text: Reliance was placed on the decisions of the Nagpur High Court in the case of S. Y. Patil v. Vyankatswami 2 and the decision of the Court of the Judicial Commissioner of Sind in the case of Suganchand v. Seth Naraindas 3 , in support of the submission that even if a person had ceased to be a public servant before the prosecution started, such a person was protected by the provisions of s. 197 of the Code and a sanction was necessary before a court could take cognizance.

precedents.cited_proposition: Sanction under s.197 CrPC required even if person ceased to be public servant before prosecution started

precedents.citation: Suganchand v. Seth Naraindas 3 A. I. R. 1932 Sind. I77

anchor.surface_text: Reliance was placed on the decisions of the Nagpur High Court in the case of S. Y. Patil v. Vyankatswami 2 and the decision of the Court of the Judicial Commissioner of Sind in the case of Suganchand v. Seth Naraindas 3 , in support of the submission that even if a person had ceased to be a public servant before the prosecution started, such a person was protected by the provisions of s. 197 of the Code and a sanction was necessary before a court could take cognizance.

precedents.cited_proposition: Sanction under s.197 CrPC required even if person ceased to be public servant before prosecution started

precedents.citation: The State v. Hifzul Rahman 1 I. L. R. 1951 Nag. 764

anchor.surface_text: It is, however, to be noticed that the decision of the Nagpur High Court, which was of a single Judge, was overruled by a Division Bench of that Court in the case of The State v. Hifzul Rahman 1 , where it was held that the person accused must be a public servant at the time of the accusation and s. 197 of the Code afforded no protection to a public servant if he had ceased to hold office.

precedents.cited_proposition: Under s.197 CrPC, person must be public servant at time of accusation; no protection if ceased to hold office
precedents.cited_holding: Person accused must be a public servant at the time of the accusation and s.197 affords no protection if ceased to hold office

precedents.citation: Prasad Chandra Banerji v. Emperor 2 1. L. R. 1944 1 Cal. 113

anchor.surface_text: In the case of Prasad Chandra Banerji v. Emperor 2 , the Calcutta High Court held that the protection given by s. 197. of the Code applied only to a person who is still a public servant at the time the prosecution is launched and does not extend to a person who is no longer a public servant at that time but was in office when the offence charged was alleged to have been committed.

precedents.cited_proposition: Protection of s.197 CrPC applies only if still public servant at time prosecution launched
precedents.cited_holding: Protection given by s.197 applies only to person still public servant at time prosecution launched

precedents.citation: Imperator v. Joshi 3 I. L. R. 1947 Bom. 706

anchor.surface_text: A similar view was taken by the Bombay High Court in the case of Imperator v. Joshi 3 , and by a single Judge of the Allahabad High Court in the case of Emperor v. Suraj Narain Chaube 4 .

precedents.cited_proposition: Protection of s.197 CrPC applies only if still public servant at time of accusation

precedents.citation: Emperor v. Suraj Narain Chaube 4 1. L. R. 1938 All. 776

anchor.surface_text: A similar view was taken by the Bombay High Court in the case of Imperator v. Joshi 3 , and by a single Judge of the Allahabad High Court in the case of Emperor v. Suraj Narain Chaube 4 . It would thus appear that the High Courts of Calcutta, Bombay, Allahabad and Nagpur are agreed that s. 197 of the Code affords no protection to a person who is not a public servant at the time he is accused of an offence before a court although at the time he committed the offence he was a public servant.

precedents.cited_proposition: Protection of s.197 CrPC applies only if still public servant at time of accusation

precedents.citation: The State v. Gurcharan Singh 5 A. I. R. 1952 Pun.89

anchor.surface_text: The decision of the Punjab High Court in the case of The State v. Gurcharan Singh 5 , was brought to our notice wherein it was held that in view of the form of wording in the two sections, namely s. 197 of the Code and s. 6 of the Act, the same principles would apply to them, having regard to the decisions of the Calcutta and Bombay High Courts and the protection afforded by s. 197 of the Code was available to a person who was a public servant while still in office but was not available to him when he had already been discharged from service before he was prosecuted.

precedents.cited_proposition: Same principles apply to s.197 CrPC and s.6 Prevention of Corruption Act; no sanction needed if not public servant at time of cognizance
precedents.cited_holding: Protection under s.6 PCA not available if discharged from service before prosecution
